item.title: Postgres Present and Future
item.description:
Description

Postgres 9.5 was just released a few months ago and has a number of of new improvements we'll walk through including new JSONB functions, some analytical tooling, and of course upsert. Then we'll dive into what's coming in Postgres 9.6, the next Postgres release. Finally, we'll round it out with some look at the ecosystem of extensions.
item.dc:creator: Craig Kerstiens

item.title: DjangoCon EU 2013: Craig Kerstiens - Getting past the Django ORM limitations with Postgres
item.description:
Description

Videos from DjangoCon Europe 2013 are kindly provided by Heroku, a cloud application platform -- a new way of building and deploying web apps: http://heroku.com/
item.dc:creator: Craig Kerstiens

item.title: Postgres present and future
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Craig Kerstiens

Postgres 9.5 was just released a few months ago and has a number of of new improvements we'll walk through including new JSONB functions, some analytical tooling, and of course upsert. Then we'll dive into what's coming in Postgres 9.6, the next Postgres release. Finally, we'll round it out with some look at the ecosystem of extensions.

Slides can be found at: https://speakerdeck.com/pycon2016 and https://github.com/PyCon/2016-slides
item.dc:creator: Craig Kerstiens

item.title: Postgres Performance for Humans
item.description:
Summary

To many developers the database is a black box. You expect to be able to put data into your database, have it to stay there, and get it out when you query it... hopefully in a performant manner. When its not performant enough the two options are usually add some indexes or throw some hardware at it. We'll walk through a bit of a clearer guide of how you can understand and manage DB performance.
item.dc:creator: Craig Kerstiens
